TIM JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY—MAY 2, 1952

Vol. LVI—No.24

56th Yeas!

4111110

Hope To Profit
From Four-day Production
Of Revised 'East Lynne'

Boosters Boosting Brings'Stormers
Score Board To Homewood

Li

a
5

"Actions speak louder than
words." seemed to be the motto
of the Booster Club as they boosted donations from several of the
major campus activities for the
Purchase of an all-metal, electric,
remote-control score board, which
Will stand on the West End of
Homewood Field soon.
Bob Marcus, Booster prexy, said
that the score board, a product
of the B. Brown Co. in Michigan,
Will have a six foot diameter clock
With electric numeral's 18 inches
high, and is capable of indicating,
Possession of the ball, yards-to-go,
downs, quarters, and a score as
high as 69. It will be used for
both Football and Lacrosse games.
Alumni Aid
The total cost of the clock was
met with the aid of the Alumni,
Who contributed $600; the "H"
Club, which donated $150; the
I.F.B., $150; the Booster Club,
$115; the Cotillion Board, $100;
the Frosh and Soph classes, $50
each; the Junior Class and the
Glee Club, $25 each; and $145
from the S.A.C. contingency fund.
The university has agreed to pay
the $400 installation fee.
The Boosters. are hoping that
this new addition to the campus

will be installed in time to register
the score of the Hopkins-Maryland
Lacrosse tilt on May 17.
Old Idea
Markus presented this age-old
idea to his club early this year. A
committee (actually the entire
Booster Club), headed by Don
Tate, was appointed to collect the
money for the project. The University had refused to pay the
initial cost.

By AL N. EPSTEIN

go to all the organizations who
helped to meet the cost of the
score board, and especially to the
successful efforts of chairman
Tate and the entire Booster Club."

Dorm Plans
Slowed Up
Continued delay in "procedure"
has held up plans for a new dormitory, according to plant manager
Wesley A. Taylor.
It was hoped that preliminary
data on the building would be
available three weeks ago. But
Taylor said this week that no information was available that was
concrete enough for publication.
Asked what has been holding
UP operations, Taylor blamed
Ild
procedure."
The new dormitory has been
Planned for the wooded section
south of the baseball field, and is
to be placed at right angles to the

strictly formal and tickets are
being issued through the IFB representatives in each of the fraternities.
The Hopkins' local dance orchestra, The Blue Jays, have been
engaged to supply music for the

ing.

evening.

In conjunction with the Alumni's plans the Booster Club will
sponsor a float, contest and a
Homecoming queen contest during half time of the Maryland lacrosse game. The theme of the
former will be any phase of "Campus Life at Hopkins" and all ideas
must be submitted, no later than
May 3, to P.O. Box 1547.
Each organization entering a
float will be eligible to enter a girl
as sponsor. The sponsor of the
winning float will be declared
queen of the week-end.

I

Blood Needed

The S.C., under chairman Warren Gruppe, will sponsor a second
"Blood-mobile" drive on Wednesday, May 7, at Levering Hall.
Last semester's one-day stand
netted 289 pints and it is hoped
that this second drive will produce
at least 100 more. Anyone over 18
may contribute; those under 21
must have parental permission.

The class of 1892, and all other
classes ending in 2 or 7 will hold
reunion dinners Saturday night.
At these dinners a special attempt
will be made to get all members
of the various classes to attend.

grandstands surround three sides
of the floor-level stage and the
permanent stage is being used as
a dressing room and for property
storage.

Second Draft
Test Planned
Major General Lewis B. Hershey,
Director of Selective Service, today announced an additional Selective Service College Qualification
Test to be held May 22, 1952,
at 1,000 testing centers for the
benefit of students prevented by
illness or other emergency from
taking the test December 13, 1951,
or April 24 of this year.

He will be available, though, for
pinch-hitting duties.
To fill the gap at the hot
corner Coach Mac Erwin will tentatively rearrange his infield by
moving second sacker John Weaver
to third, short-stop Angie Fortunato over to second, transplanting catcher Bucky Myers to the
short field, and inserting hustling
John McDonough back of the plate.
In an effort to better their 1-3
record for the year, the basebailers battled Towson yesterday
and will take on the Western
Maryland nine at the Marylander's
field tomorrow.

Frosh Netmen
Dump City 74
A 7-1 triumph over City College
brought the season's record of the
frosh netmen to one win and two
defeats. City is the 'defending
scholastic champion. The losses
were to Loyola and Forest Park
high schools.

Indoors or out, when you see a crowd of campus biggies
relaxing, you're sure to notice that the really smart boys
are wearing Manhattan Sportshirts. The reason is as.
simple as a snap course. Manhattan Sportshirts are styleright, handsomely tailored, and so darned comfortable
you just hate to take'em off. Manhattan has them in long
and short sleeves ... in a wide variety of colors and
patterns all in the finest fabrics. All are the sportiest you
could put on your back when you want to take it easy!

'East Lynne'Hilarious

the spirit of the thing and pay
him his boos.
The humor is certainly not subtle; its uproarousness comes from
the fact• that it hits with no
punches spared. Added to this,
Astin's interpretation of the classic is a wealth of new twists,
such as the presentation in the
round, which is skillfully accomplished. This is production-wise
one of the best integrated Stormer
shows we've seen in a long time.
Since this is probably our last
wad of drama criticism on the
Nz.ws-Letter, we rest our reputation with this play. It's a safe bet.

Vol. LVI—No.24

Hope To Profit
From Four-day Production
Of Revised 'East Lynne'

Boosters Boosting Brings'Stormers
Score Board To Homewood

Li

a
5

"Actions speak louder than
words." seemed to be the motto
of the Booster Club as they boosted donations from several of the
major campus activities for the
Purchase of an all-metal, electric,
remote-control score board, which
Will stand on the West End of
Homewood Field soon.
Bob Marcus, Booster prexy, said
that the score board, a product
of the B. Brown Co. in Michigan,
Will have a six foot diameter clock
With electric numeral's 18 inches
high, and is capable of indicating,
Possession of the ball, yards-to-go,
downs, quarters, and a score as
high as 69. It will be used for
both Football and Lacrosse games.
Alumni Aid
The total cost of the clock was
met with the aid of the Alumni,
Who contributed $600; the "H"
Club, which donated $150; the
I.F.B., $150; the Booster Club,
$115; the Cotillion Board, $100;
the Frosh and Soph classes, $50
each; the Junior Class and the
Glee Club, $25 each; and $145
from the S.A.C. contingency fund.
The university has agreed to pay
the $400 installation fee.
The Boosters. are hoping that
this new addition to the campus

will be installed in time to register
the score of the Hopkins-Maryland
Lacrosse tilt on May 17.
Old Idea
Markus presented this age-old
idea to his club early this year. A
committee (actually the entire
Booster Club), headed by Don
Tate, was appointed to collect the
money for the project. The University had refused to pay the
initial cost.

Markus stated, "credit should
go to all the organizations who
helped to meet the cost of the
score board, and especially to the
successful efforts of chairman
Tate and the entire Booster Club."

Dorm Plans
Slowed Up
Continued delay in "procedure"
has held up plans for a new dormitory, according to plant manager
Wesley A. Taylor.
It was hoped that preliminary
data on the building would be
available three weeks ago. But
Taylor said this week that no information was available that was
concrete enough for publication.
Asked what has been holding
UP operations, Taylor blamed
Ild
procedure."
The new dormitory has been
Planned for the wooded section
south of the baseball field, and is
to be placed at right angles to the

strictly formal and tickets are
being issued through the IFB representatives in each of the fraternities.
The Hopkins' local dance orchestra, The Blue Jays, have been
engaged to supply music for the

ing.

evening.

In conjunction with the Alumni's plans the Booster Club will
sponsor a float, contest and a
Homecoming queen contest during half time of the Maryland lacrosse game. The theme of the
former will be any phase of "Campus Life at Hopkins" and all ideas
must be submitted, no later than
May 3, to P.O. Box 1547.
Each organization entering a
float will be eligible to enter a girl
as sponsor. The sponsor of the
winning float will be declared
queen of the week-end.

I

Blood Needed

The S.C., under chairman Warren Gruppe, will sponsor a second
"Blood-mobile" drive on Wednesday, May 7, at Levering Hall.
Last semester's one-day stand
netted 289 pints and it is hoped
that this second drive will produce
at least 100 more. Anyone over 18
may contribute; those under 21
must have parental permission.

The class of 1892, and all other
classes ending in 2 or 7 will hold
reunion dinners Saturday night.
At these dinners a special attempt
will be made to get all members
of the various classes to attend.

of the floor-level stage and the
permanent stage is being used as
a dressing room and for property

Second Draft
Test Planned
Major General Lewis B. Hershey,
Director of Selective Service, today announced an additional Selective Service College Qualification
Test to be held May 22, 1952,
at 1,000 testing centers for the
benefit of students prevented by
illness or other emergency from
taking the test December 13, 1951,
or April 24 of this year.

Frosh Netmen
Dump City 74
A 7-1 triumph over City College
brought the season's record of the
frosh netmen to one win and two
defeats. City is the 'defending
scholastic champion. The losses
were to Loyola and Forest Park
high schools.

Indoors or out, when you see a crowd of campus biggies
relaxing, you're sure to notice that the really smart boys
are wearing Manhattan Sportshirts. The reason is as.
simple as a snap course. Manhattan Sportshirts are styleright, handsomely tailored, and so darned comfortable
you just hate to take'em off. Manhattan has them in long
and short sleeves ... in a wide variety of colors and
patterns all in the finest fabrics. All are the sportiest you
could put on your back when you want to take it easy!

the spirit of the thing and pay

The humor is certainly not subtle; its uproarousness comes from
the fact• that it hits with no
punches spared. Added to this,
Astin's interpretation of the classic is a wealth of new twists,
such as the presentation in the
round, which is skillfully accomplished. This is production-wise
one of the best integrated Stormer
shows we've seen in a long time.
Since this is probably our last
wad of drama criticism on the
Nz.ws-Letter, we rest our reputation with this play. It's a safe bet.
